subject: Fix Neutron Authentication for Metadata Service
commit_message:
Fix Neutron Authentication for Metadata Service

A recent change to the way Nova creates a Neutron client
51e5f52e4cb60e266ccde71f205c91eb8c97b48b changed the conditions
under which it re-authenticates using the neutron admin credentials
from "if admin" to "if admin or context.is_admin".  However this
meant that any user with admin role in Nova interacted with Neutron
as a different tenant, preventing them from non-admin actions such
as allocating floating IPS.

This was then addressed by 1c1371c78b990447aeaa4377b512f8887e6ff3ce
which only reauthenticated as admin on the explicit use of
"admin=True" parameter to neutonv2.get_client().

However the metadata service does not explicitly create the neutron
client so it has to pass in a context created by
context.get_admin_context() which has is_admin=True but no auth_token.

This change therefore accepts this combination of context values
as a valid reason to re-authenticate as admin, while still allowing
users with the admin role to use their own token.

As a tidy up two tests for getting an admin client are moved from
TestNeutonClient to join the other admin client tests in
TestNeutronClientForAdminScenarios

Change-Id: Ic2a6f383a85f6bb606d8d65feaefa0d23329adb9
Closes-Bug:  1255577

Run benchmark scenarios for a given period of time

This patch introduces a new parameter to the benchmark config, namely
the "duration" parameter. In case it is used instead of the "times"
parameter in the config, it specifies the period of time (in minutes)
during which the benchmark should be launched over and over (so that
the actual amount of scenario runs gets undefined).

A benchmark config which would launch booting/deleting servers concurrently
from several users/tenants during 5 minutes would then look like this:

"benchmark": {
    "NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server": [
        {"args": {"flavor_id": 1,
                  "image_id": "73257560-c59b-4275-a1ec-ab140e5b9979"},
         "execution": "continuous",
         "config": {"duration": 5, "active_users": 2,

}

commit_message:
Fail when image is bigger than the volume

When creating a new volume from a qcow2 image stored in glance, we will
be given the physical size of the image instead of the virtual size.
Most drivers will convert that image to raw after downloading for
resizing it to the requested volume size afterwards.

If the virtual size of the image is bigger than the requested one, the
resulting volume might end up being unusable after the resize even
though the creation went good.

This patch will make the volume creation fail if the virtual size of

or False. This worked fine for values whose default value
was False. 'enabled', however, has a default value of True.

value since it wasn't explicitly stated. Instead of changing
the unit tests, the solution is to only send the value in the
first place if it is not the default value, using argparse's
default mechanism. If it is the default, then it is written as

subject: Protect against hash cleanup errors on PUTs
commit_message:
Protect against hash cleanup errors on PUTs

In http://launchpad.net/bugs/1254405 an exception occurs when
finalizing the PUT of an object, but it is obscured by the thread pool
code, so we don't see the actual line where it originated. However,
there are two possible functions where this exception could originate:

    1. renamer()
    2. hash_cleanup_listdir()

If this is an error in renamer(), there is some other waky problem
where the temporary file has been removed. It is likely that this is a
problem where a file name from os.listdir ends up disappearing (but
even this is a rare occurence). Regardless, it is not clear that we
really want an error from hash_cleanup_listdir() from affecting the
return result of the PUT.

To that end, we squelsh OSErrors from hash_cleanup_listdir() for
now. One might argue for all errors, but since os.unlink() and
os.listdir() raise OSError today, that is probably sufficient.

determined that this closes that bug report.

subject: Do not format messages before they are logged
commit_message:
Do not format messages before they are logged

The python logging facility allows for the logging message to contain
string formatting commands, and will format that string with any
additional arguments provided. It will only perform this formatting if
the logging level allows.

So if you have:

   A. logging.debug("this %s that %s", this, that)
   B. logging.debug("this %s that %s" % (this, that))

Then A only formats the message if the debug logging level is set,
where as B will always format the message. Since this filter is often
on the fast-path for swift requests, it will help the small object
case to avoid any extra possible work.

subject: Add SLDs that act like TLDs
commit_message:
Add SLDs that act like TLDs

This change is from the Icehouse release. The effective TLD file need
not be present. When it is not present the behavior would be the same
as before. When it is present, the domains that are being created are
checked to see that it is not an effective TLD.

This change offers the designate administrator the ability to configure
2 lists to indicate the TLDs(accepted_tlds_file) and SLDs and others
that effectively act as TLDs.(effective_tlds_file)

2 sample files are included to show the format required for these files.
The TLD file is from http://data.iana.org/TLD/tlds-alpha-by-domain.txt
Commented lines in this file begin with a #. There is one entry per line
and the entries are in the IDNA format.

The sample effective TLD file is from http://publicsuffix.org/list/
This file is in the UTF-8 format. Lines beginning with a // and ! are
ignored. The wildcard character * (asterisk) may only be used to
wildcard the topmost level in a domain name. All the entries are
converted to idna format.

subject: Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class
commit_message:
Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class

Since the DiskFile class is the abstraction layer for the needs of the
REST API layer, it seems that the auditor should not use the same
methods in order to truly "audit". Instead, only the low-level on-disk
file logic for the data directory is shared, and all other
verifications are performed using direct inspections of the data. All
the on-disk logic remains in the diskfile module.

As a result, the auditor performs a few more double checks to make
sure the "name" metadata attribute results in the same object data
file; adds some explicit error checking for quarantinable errors (bad
metadata, name does not hash back to the same data directory, unable
to open the file, unable to fstat the file). However, while the
current code will read the entire file only to find out that it does
not have a stored ETag, this code will quarantine an object that is
missing an ETag.

The diskfile module's get_data_file() function returns the name
triple, account, container and object, even though there are no
immediate consumers of it, as there are external to the swift code
base daemons written that can take advantage of that to also ween
themselves off of the DiskFile class.

We also use this opportunity to bring the test coverage to 99%.

Possible related work:

  * Check that the X-Timestamp metadata value matches the given name
    of the object data file
